Description: Limestone statue of a bird, head missing, crudely carved from softwhitish limestone with details mostly incised, surface now brownish with dirt.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Bird figures in stone were rare at Naukratis. Two examples with movable heads (Cairo TR14/9/18/11; Edinburgh A.1886.518.6 I; Petrie 1886, 40) were possibly toys, whilst a single flat bird figure with a fixed head (Boston 86.164) is of uncertain function or context. Similar to pieces dated 6th to 4th century BC by Petrie (Petrie 1886, 40, Pl.19.1&3, who discusses limestone bird figurines on page 40), and pieces found in 5th century BC well deposits by Hogarth Hogarth 1905, 122, 125; Hogarth 1903 Diary April 24th and 25th, well 2 bottom). Pencil mark on underside "7" = number of object in inventory of stone objects.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CE.204) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
